description:
How to run Centrifuge  version 1.0.4-beta (Kim et al. 2016) through the iMicrobe plaform.

 

Centrifuge is a microbial classification engine that enables rapid, accurate, and sensitive taxonomic labeling of metagenomic reads and quantification of species. The system uses an indexing scheme based on the Burrows-Wheeler transform (BWT) and the Ferragina-Manzini (FM) index, optimized specifically for the metagenomic classification problem. 

 

More informations about centrifuge can be found here : https://ccb.jhu.edu/software/centrifuge/manual.shtml
before_start:
• You need a working Cyverse account to connect to iMicrobe.
    To explore how to log into iMicrobe, read the dedicated protocol. 
  • Your dataset of interest should be metagenomic reads, in a fasta or fastq format.

  • In iMicrobe, there is several ways to run an app on a dataset (from the cart, from your personnal datastore and form an URL). If you need more information on how to run an app, read the protocol associated.
guidelines:
{"blocks":[{"key":"897vc","text":"More informations and details about Centrifuge can be found here : https://ccb.jhu.edu/software/centrifuge/manual.shtml ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":120,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ci0te","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1ujc","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eilkh","text":"Several parameters are available to the user through the iMicrobe app. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":70,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aipnq","text":"Index : 
Centrifuge indexes are the reference databases used for the taxonomic classification. Standard choices are all of the complete RefSeq prokaryotic, human and viral genomes, or using the sequences that are part of the NCBI nt database.
The indexes provided in iMicrobe are provided by the tool authors, available here. The updataing dates for the indeces are the following :  ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":5,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":310,"length":14,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"blpc8","text":"Bacteria, Archea, Virus, Human : 12/06/2016","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62pso","text":"Bacteria, Archea : 4/15/2018","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70v07","text":"NCBI nt : 3/3/2018","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au11e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bkuq3","text":"Exclude :
A comma-separated list of taxonomic IDs that will be excluded in classification procedure. The descendants from these IDs will also be excluded. To find the taxonomic ID, one can use the NCBI taxonomic browser. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":197,"length":22,"key":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"2cfg7","text":"File format :
The user can provide a Fasta or a Fastq formated file as an input. Please use the drop down menu to select to correct format for your file.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":11,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"pa31","text":"Reads are paired :
If you are working on illumina paired reads, select that option to allow the reads to be paired before their taxonomic assignment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":17,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"kr7d","text":"Figure title :
The iMicrobe Centrifuge app provides a bubble-chart representation of the result. The title of the vizualization can be changed.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":14,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"ftp://ftp.ccb.jhu.edu/pub/infphilo/centrifuge/data"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Taxonomy/Browser/wwwtax.cgi"}}}}
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

Click on 'Browse and view output files in the CyVerse Datastore'.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f3fo","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8vn5j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5jt00","text":"a","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":4}],"data":[]},{"key":"3vsau","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a26al","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"66hvl","text":"In the job folder created in the CyVerse datastore, the input fasta/fastq files are copied, along with the logs of the job (*.err and *.out). In order to retrieve your results go to the centrifuge-out folder. It contains two folders : ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2fuv","text":"figures Contains a bubble plot vizualization of the results. The species name are displayed on the left side of the chart, and the abundance is represented by dots of increasing size. Any hits with a global abundance below 2% are removed from the chart.  A csv file accompanies the chart, and displays the name and proportion of each species found in the submited samples. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"bold"},{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c3k79","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9887e","text":"reports This folder contains the centrifuge outputs. Two types of files will be produced : ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"bold"},{"offset":0,"length":7,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d6mrh","text":"*.sum This is the classic centrifuge output. It display the taxonomic assigment found for each read. This output has 8 columns. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":5,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8r7l","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dai7h","text":"a","type":"atomic","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":5}],"data":[]},{"key":"2mghg","text":" The first column is the read ID The second column is the genomic sequence ID for which a hit was found The third column is the taxonomic ID for this genomic sequence The fourth column is th score for this classification, corresponding to a weighted sum of hits The fifth column is the score of the next best classification for this read The sixth column shows the approximate number of base pairs of the read matching the genomic sequence The seventh column shows and the length of the read (or combined length of mate pairs) The eigth column shows the number of classifications found for this reads ","type":"unstyled","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"68hnc","text":"*.tsv This output shows a classification summary for each genome or taxonomic unit. This output has 7 columns. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":5,"style":"bold"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ddlvk","text":"a","type":"atomic","depth":1,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":6}],"data":[]},{"key":"7n1p3","text":" The first column is the name of the genome The second column is the Taxonomic ID for this genome The third column is the taxonomic rank of the genome The fourth column is the length of the genome sequence in base pairs The fifth column is the number of reads from the sample classified to this genome (including multi-classified reads) The sixth column is the number of reads uniquely classified to this genome The seventh column is the proportion of this genome normlized by its genomic lengthreports
